author: Reuters
description: Facebook said it discovered a bug in its video carousel ad system.
title: Facebook to Reimburse Some Advertisers After Overcharging

author: Reuters
description: The fine is over Facebook's ability to match user identities
title: EU Fines Facebook $122 Million For ‘Misleading Information’ in Its WhatsApp Deal

author: Colin  Daileda
description: In France and the Netherlands, Facebook is allegedly violating user privacy.
title: European nations fine Facebook over being cagey with users' data

author: Mike Shields
description: Google, Amazon and Facebook all see an opportunity to disrupt TV advertising. Among the three tech giants, Facebook has perhaps chosen the toughest route.
title: Facebook's plan to disrupt TV advertising may have hit a wall

author: Mathew Ingram
description: The latest mistake feeds right into the TV industry's argument that Facebook is not to be trusted.
title: Facebook’s Latest Ad Measurement Error Comes at the Worst Possible Time

author: Contributor
description: The government of Thailand has backed down on a threat to ban Facebook if it did not block content deemed to be illegal in the country. The ruling military..
title: Thailand backs down on threat to ban Facebook

author: Mike Shields
description: The big TV networks are using their 'upfront' ad sales presentations to point out Facebook and Google's recent advertising mishaps
title: TV networks are kicking Facebook and Google while they are down

author: Reuters Editorial
description: Facebook (FB.O) has been fined 150,000 euros ($166,000) by France's data protection watchdog for failing to prevent its users' data being accessed by advertisers.
title: Facebook fined 150,000 euros by French data watchdog

author: Natalia Drozdiak
description: Facebook was fined $122.7 million by the EU’s antitrust regulator for misleading authorities over the acquisition of its messaging unit WhatsApp, firing a warning shot to other companies.
title: Facebook Slapped With EU Fine Over WhatsApp Deal

author: http://www.abc.net.au/news/paul-crossley/7901826
description: Facebook says its mission is to give people the power to share but what happens when its users choose to share a murder live online?
title: When Facebook livestreams a murder, who's responsible?
